Notes for JOHN THOMAS BOATRIGHT:

The Daily Democrat-News, Marshall, Thursday, April 8, 1926

Funeral of Tom Boatright - Services at Methodist Church conducted by the Rev. T. B. Harris Funeral Services for John Thomas Boatright who died Sunday morning at his home near Wanamaker following accidental poisoning from arsenic, were held shortly after 12 o'clock this afternoon at the Methodist church.

The funeral was set for 11 o'clock but the body, accompanied by members of the family, came overland from Sweet Springs and the arrival of the cortege here was delayed nearly an hour because of the bad conditions of the roads. Teams were stationed at the worst mudholes to assist in getting the hearse and motor cars through.

The services were conducted by the Rev. Thomas B. Harris. He preached a comforting sermon at the church and conducted the commitment service at the grave in Ridge Park cemetery.

At the church a choir composed of A. R. James, Will Koontz, Mrs. F. C. Barnhill and Mrs. Homer Rich sang "Jesus, Lover of My Soul," "Rock of Ages" and "What a Friend We Have in Jesus." The piano accompaniment was by Mrs. Lee Thomason.

The service at the grave was held in a driving rain.

Notes for FRANK RIGGINS BOATRIGHT:

Marshall, The Daily Democrat-News, Thursday, December 24, 1964

Judge Frank R. Boatright Dies of Heart Attack - County Court Associate was at School Program.

Judge Frank R. Boatright, 58 years old, Route 2, Marshall, passed away unexpectedly of an apparent heart attack last night while attending the Christmas program at the Green Mound school, near the Boatright home.

Funeral services will be at 2 o'clock Saturday afternoon in the Marshall Methodist church. The Rev. Arnold Prater, church minister, will officiate and burial will be in Ridge Park cemetery.

Judge Boatright was born July 10, 1906 in Saline county, the son of the late John William and Cora Riggins Boatright. With the exception of two years when Judge and Mrs. Boatright resided in the Elmwood community, he had lived his entire life on the farm where he was born.

February 24, 1931 he was married to Miss Edith Shrader, who survives of the home. Judge Boatright joined the Hazel Grove Methodist church at an early age and had been Associate Judge of the First District of the County Court and a member of the Democrat committee for several years.

Surviving besides his wife of the home, are two sons Dr. B. L. Boatright of Sedalia, and John E. Boatright, Route 3, Marshall; three grand children, Daniel Kevin, Deborah Karel and Mariam Ruth Boatright of Sedalia; two sisters, Mrs. A. J. Dingley of Marshall and Mrs. Oliver Nightwine, Sweet Springs.

He was preceeded in death by two brothers and two sisters.

Notes for LUCY ELLEN ROTHROCK:

Marshall, The Democrat-News, Saturday, August 30, 1980

Lucy R. Boatright, 79, of Marshall, died Friday, August 19 at Bothwell Hospital in Sedalia. Services will be held at 2 p.m. Sunday at the Campbell-Lewis Chapel. The Rev. Byron Banta will officiate. Burial will be in the Ridge Park Cemetery. Visitation will be from 7 to 8:30 p.m. Saturday at the Chapel.

Born May 4, 1901 in Saline County, Mo., she was the daughter of the late Samuel Rothrock and Mary Florence Mayse Rothrock. She was married in 1919 in Saline County to Frank Oliver Crain who preceded her in death in 1922. On Sept. 2, 1925 she was married to Harry R. Boatright who proceded her in death March 10, 1966. Mrs. Boatright was a member of the First Christian Church and has resided in Saline County most of her life.

Survivors include one son, Robert E. Boatright of Lee's Summit, Mo.; one daughter, Mrs. Rogers (Norene) Clark of Marshall; three grandchildren; one great-grandchild; one sister, Mrs. Vernie (Pauline) Aldridge of Sweet Springs.

She was preceded in death by one brother and one grandson.

Memorials are suggested to the Missouri Valley College.

Graveside services will be at 11 a.m. Saturday at the Ridge Park Cemetery, Marshall, MO., cremation. Mrs. Phillips was born in Saline County, Mo., and moved to this area 40 years ago. She was a house mother for student nurses enrolled in the Bethany Hospital School of Nursing for 17 years before she retired. She was a Presbyterian. Her husband, King M. Phillips, died in 1956. Survivors include a daughter, Ermalee R. Smith, Topeka, and three grandchildren.

The Kansas City Star, July 28, 1992.

WILLIAM GOLAY BOATRIGHT (GEORGE FRANCIS10, WILLIAM GREENE9, JACOB8, JACOB7, WILLIAM6, THOMAS5, JOHN4, JOHN3, JOHN2, Not Yet Determined1) was born 21 Jul 1896 in Houstonia, Pettis County, Missouri, and died 03 Feb 1959 in Kansas City, Jackson County, Missouri. Notes for WILLIAM GOLAY BOATRIGHT:

A lifelong resident of Missouri and a member of the Kansas City bar for more than forty years, William G. Boatright had to his credit a distinguished record of practice, particularly in the field of antitrust law, in which he won a wide reputation. He was attorney in a number of precedent-making cases, and he found time in a busy life for many other useful activities, particularly on behalf of his church.

He was a native of Pettis County, Missouri, and was born on July 31, 1896, the son of George Francis and Laura Belle (Golay) Boatright. His grandfather, William Green Boatright, a resident of Saline County, Missouri, was born in 1830 and died in 1921. His paternal grandmother was Nancy Frances Buie, who was born in 1839 and died in 1914.

Reared on a farm near Sedalia, Missouri, William G. Boatright attended the public schools, and graduated from Sedalia High School. He studied law in the offices of Lamm, Bohling & Lamm at Sedalia. He was admitted to the bar of the State of Missouri in July 1917. After serving in the armed forces during World War I, he became associated with the Ringolsky & Friedman law offices in Kansas City, Missouri, becoming a partner in the firm in 1924 with offices in the Lanthrop Building. This organization became Ringolsky, Boatright & Jacobs in 1929, and Mr. Boatright remained with that firm until March 1941, when he left to practice independently, with offices in the Commerce Building.

Mr. Boatright was widely recognized and respected for meticulous, skilful and thorough preparation of his cases. Weeks spent in research, study and examination of all possible directions to which testimony and trial developments might lead and his deep sense of obligation to clients won for him outstanding recognition as a truly fine trial lawyer.

When, in the 1930s, Kansas City became a focus of national attention by reason of its vote fraud trials, he was engaged as trial attorney by several defendants.

In 1945, he was appointed by the Alien Property Custodian of the United States, under an executive order, to represent certain enemy aliens in litigation involving the will and estate of Conrad H. Mann, deceased. He achieved outstanding results in this lengthy and complicated litigation.

in 1950, he was trial attorney for plaintiff in an action for treble damages against Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and eight other major motion picture film companies. After seven weeks of trial, he was successful in obtaining for his client, Brookside Theatre Corporation, a verdict of $375,000 damages, which was automatically trebled under a provision of the Federal antitrust laws.

In 1952, he represented the Electric Theatre Company in a similar treble-damage action against these same major motion picture film companies, obtaining for his client a treble-damage judgement of approximately $2,400,000, in addition to important first-run film contracts. This case was settled along with eight other motion picture cases which he had brought involving other theatre owners against the powerful motion picture interests.

In 1953, he was chief trial attorney in an action brought on behalf of Harzfeld's Inc. for damages against the Otis Elevator Company resulting from the fall of an elevator. On eve of trial Mr. Boatright was successful in securing an outstanding settlement for client.

He was one of the organizers of the Lawyers Association of Kansas City in which he retained membership. He was also a member of the Kansas City Bar Association, the Missouri Bar Association, and the American Bar Association. His non-professional connections included the Carriage Club and the Henry County Hunting Club. He belonged to Country Club Lodge No. 656, the Masonic Lodge, Scottish Rite, Shrine Ararat Temple, and American Legion Post No. 50.

Mr. Boatright entered military service in May 1917. He attended the First Officers' Training Camp and served as Lieutenant in the 79th Field Artillery. He was overseas with the Expeditionary Forces from August, 1918 until June, 1919; however, he served as Captain in the Officers' Reserve Corp, 177th Field Artillery, until 1933.

A Democrat in his politics, Mr. Boatright was much sought after as a speaker in behalf of his party's candidates, but never sought nor accepted candidacy himself.

Among the major interests outside of his profession was the Methodist Church in which he was an active layman for more than forty years. He served the denomination in many capacities and later in his own church, St. John's Methodist Church, as steward, trustee, teacher, youth leader and committee member. On more than one occasion he was Chairman of the Board of Trustees and Vice Chairman of the Official Board. Before the present St. John's Methodist Church was built, he was a charter member of the Brookside Methodist Church and on its Official Board. He was one of the leaders in the organization to its present site on Ward Parkway under the new name of St. John's Methodist Church. In later years, he attended services at Central Methodist Church. An outstanding Methodist clergyman of Kansas City, having first-hand knowledge of Mr. Boatright's work and activities has commented:

"He felt strongly on certain matters, for example he thought the church ought to be the church and not merely the tool in the hands of interested spectators. He never shirked what he considered to be his responsibility. He was extremely careful in carrying out every point, great and small, in Methodist polity... He knew the Bible well and had a deep sense of exposition."

One cannot begin to characterize his life without emphasizing his love for his family and the enjoyment he so plainly showed in the company and fellowship of his friends. He was keenly interested in sports, particularly fishing and hunting, and in gardening, agriculture and photography. He was an ardent student of history, political science and government. The quality of his mind and broadness of spirit enable him to be a self-educated man of rare exception.

At Marshall, Missouri, on August 12, 1917, William Golay Boatright married Elithe Belwood, daughter of Foree and Ginevra (Hoffman) Belwood. The couple became the parents of one daughter, Billie, who was born on December 9, 1918. She is the wife of Harmon Lynn Elder, of Washington D.C., and they have two sons: William Lynn and James Michael.

Mr. Boatright's death occurred at his home in Kansas City on February 3, 1959.

Source: Encyclopedia of American Biography, Volume XXX, under the editorial direction of Winfield Scott Downs, published 1960.



William Golay Boatright and Mary Elithe Belwood wed on August 12, 1917, in Marshall, Missouri. William was already training with the 79th Field Artillery since May of 1917. He was overseas with the Expeditionary Forces from August, 1918 until June, 1919. Daughter Elithe was born on December 9, 1918, four months after he shipped out for Europe.

Boatright, William G. of Kansas City, Jackson County, Missour Democrat. Delegate to Democratic National Convention from Missouri, 1940.



The Sedalia Democrat, Wednesday, February 4, 1959

William G. Boatright, 62, a native of Pettis County, died in his sleep Monday night at his home, 1020 West 67th St. Terrace, Kansas City. He was born east of Houstonia where his younger years were spent.

For 40 years he practiced law in Kansas City and he had been an expert in the field of antitrust legislation.

For several months he had been ill with a heart ailment and in November and part of December had been a patient at Trinity Lutheran Hospital, Kansas City. He returned to his home about six weeks ago and resumed visiting his office on a part time basis.

Remembering my Dad, Dean Duggins Boatright, Sr.

by Ned Collins Boatright - June 2001

Dean Duggins Boatright, Sr. was a remarkable person. He was born on June 22, 1898 on a Missouri dirt farm. He died in Rochester, Minnesota on August 22, 1994 at age 96. During all of these years he evolved from a nave country boy with a high school education into a business manager who spent 40 years of his life working for S. S. Kresge Company. Dean met my mother, Mildred, while attending Sadalia High School. One day after she died, I was visiting him and he drove me by the house where Mother lived with her family when he was courting her. It was almost dark, and he stopped the car in front of a frame house with a porch that ran across the front of the house. He told me that he and Mother used to sit in the swing on that porch and talk about their future. He then broke into tears. I have a picture of them taken on their wedding day - October 10, 1920. The picture reveals, in aging and sepia tones, a tall, gangling, large-handed countrified young man of 22, and a shy, lovely, musically gifted young woman of 23. Their eyes did not reflect, nor did they know, what the future held for them, but they went through it together - until death did indeed part them on October 30, 1978, 58 years later.

Dad was a workaholic. Through the years I became aware of his character and characteristics, beginning as I entered my teens during the 1930's. I realized then that he was engrossed constantly in his work as a Kresge store manager. He would leave for work around 7:00am each of the six mornings when the store was open, and return home from work around 7:00pm each evening. He ate lunch at the fountain in the store. He therefore spent at least 11 hours a day there, and then on Sunday would return to the store after Sunday church and dinner, to spend 3 hours changing the store window displays. Altogether he devoted 60 percent of his waking hours forty years of his life working for Kresge. At age 65 he retired and received a pension of $400 a month.

Upon returning home each evening, Mother would say, "How was your day?" Dad would then say with a lift in his voice, "we had an increase" or with an unenthusiastic response, "we had a decrease". I learned in my elementary school years that this "coded" language meant that the sales of the store that day were either higher than or lower
